sub_topic: Finding the volume of a sphere inscribed in a cube.
message_1: A cube has a side length of 10 cm. What is the volume of the largest possible sphere that can be inscribed within the cube? (Round the answer to the nearest hundredth)
message_2:
To inscribe the largest possible sphere within a cube, the diameter of the sphere must be equal to the side length of the cube. In this case, the side length of the cube is 10 cm, so the diameter of the sphere is also 10 cm. The radius of the sphere is half of the diameter, which is 5 cm.

The volume of a sphere is given by the formula:

V = (4/3)πr^3

where V is the volume and r is the radius.

Substituting the radius value into the formula:

V = (4/3)π(5)^3
V = (4/3)π(125)
V = 500π/3

Now, we can approximate the value of π as 3.14:

V ≈ (500 * 3.14) / 3
V ≈ 1570 / 3
V ≈ 523.33 cm^3

So, the volume of the largest possible sphere that can be inscribed within the cube is approximately 523.33 cm^3, rounded to the nearest hundredth.
